Top_n_words: book - writer - author - list - bookshop - read - library - year - reading - paperback
original_text: Authors - if you‚Äôre invited to take part in a festival, ask who else is invited and what they‚Äôre speaking about. If the line up has no Black writers, or if Black writers are only asked to speak about identity or Black pain, say you won‚Äôt speak until the festival does better.
label: Life

Top_n_words: people - time - year - today - thing - week - news - game - story - work
original_text: Publicists - don‚Äôt ignore Black reviewers/critics for 95% of the books you‚Äôre working on, and then only get in touch when you have a book by a Black author or illustrator. It‚Äôs really, really obvious, and really, really not appreciated.
label: None

Top_n_words: people - time - year - today - thing - week - news - game - story - work
original_text: Also for publicists, and related to my point about authors, examine the line ups for festivals and venues that you‚Äôre pitching authors to. Ensure they‚Äôre inclusive, and if they‚Äôre not, flag it with them.
label: None

Top_n_words: book - writer - author - list - bookshop - read - library - year - reading - paperback
original_text: Retailers - look at where you‚Äôre placing books by Black authors in your bookshop. Have you got them on tables? Are these books face out? Do you choose them for window displays? If your answer is no, time to rearrange.
label: Life

Top_n_words: people - time - year - today - thing - week - news - game - story - work
original_text: Reviewers/critics - if you read a proof and find racist sentiments/sentences/ideas and/or a portrayal of Black people based on stereotypes, email the publicist to point it out. Don‚Äôt let it lie and assume someone else will notice, or that it‚Äôs not a big enough thing to point out.
label: None
